newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: Kazakhstan, EBRD mull $200 mln railway project.
newsitem.headline: Kazakhstan, EBRD mull $200 mln railway project.

text.p: Kazakhstan will take tough measures to attract funds from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) to modernise its indebted railways, Prime Minister Akezhan Kazhegeldin said on Friday.

"We support your proposal to raise tariffs and eliminate debts to make our railway network profitable...The government will offer its guarantees for the project," Kazhegeldin told a meeting with the bank's mission.

Kazakhstan -- a resource-rich former Soviet republic five times the size of France -- wants to use its geographical position as a transit link between Europe and Asia. Kazakhstan borders Russia, China and the other states of Central Asia.
Kazhegeldin said the government was planning to make the loss-making railways important contributors to the budget and the economy.
But first the railways must be radically restructured.
Bernard Ziller, EBRD senior banker in charge of the project, told Reuters after the meeting that the total cost of the project would amount to around $200 million.
"The European Bank might go up to $100 million, and usually in big projects like railway restructuring we are cooperating with other financial institutions," he said.
He said the EBRD now expected the government to start resolving the arrears amassed by national railways.
Kazhegeldin told Ziller that the 12 billion tenge ($160 million) debts were incurred in recent years when clients preferred to pay not in cash but in kind.
"The railways will now have to sell some of their assets to turn them into cash. We also insist that the railways must provide their services only for advanced payments," he said.
Ziller said the government would take these steps over the next few months.
"I guess by November-December this year we will finalise our negotiations to start practical work next year," he said.
Kazhegeldin said the restructuring would make it possible to preserve the 300,000 jobs of its workers.
EBRD officials said other projects with the Central Asian state would follow.
"Kazakhstan is becoming increasingly important in the EBRD investment strategy," said Ferdinando Buffoni, EBRD Resident Representative in Kazakhstan.
The country has already attracted billions of dollars in investment commitments, but they are mostly in the potentially lucrative energy sector.
"We are trying to attract investors not only in our promising oil and gas sector," Kazhegeldin said.
"Investing in Kazakhstan must become as strong a habit as skiing in Switzerland," he said.
